text: [Music]
hi I'm Leo xowski I'm a principal
Solutions architect with AWS today we're
going to go over an introduction to AWS
Cloud9 our Cloud ID that lets you write
run and debug code so let's get started
the first thing we need to do is spin up
an AWS Cloud9 environment to do this
let's go to the AWS console in a web
browser and go to AWS Cloud9 where you
can click on create
environment the next step is to give the
aw Cloud9 environment we just created a
name on the configure settings screen
let's choose the default settings and
click create
environment in the next few minutes we
will have a fully functional AWS Cloud9
ID up and
running here's the AWS Cloud9
environment on the left you can see a
listing of my projects since I just
started this environment I don't have
any here yet but we'll fix that shortly
on the right you can see the AWS Cloud9
code editor
below that is a fully functional
terminal which ABS Cloud 9 has built
in the first thing we need to do is
change the default
theme we should also change the key
bindings I'm going to change it to Vim
since this is obviously the right choice
here something that's really useful in
AWS Cloud 9 is the built-in ads
integration I'm going to jump over to
AWS settings now here we can change the
default AWS region and change how IM
credentials are configured the AWS CLI
is pre-installed and preconfigured in
AWS
cloud99 let's now check to see what S3
buckets we have in my AWS
account all we have to do is type A CLI
command in the terminal window and you
will see that it will work out of the
box having all this run through a web
browser is super helpful because you
could be on a laner laptop a tablet or
some machine that doesn't have a lot of
power as long as you have a web browser
you will get the same experience as I am
showing you
here now let's edit some code my code is
in an AWS code commit
repository git is pre-installed with ads
Cloud 9 so all we need to do is just
clone the
repository we have to type in a few
commands which configure the credentials
for the code commit repository so let's
do that
[Music]
now the repository can now be
cloned now let's open up both the e
cloud formation template and the shell
script the cloud formation template
spins up a few Amazon
workspaces A bash script currently
describes which workspaces I have
running in my AWS
account AWS Cloud9 has syntax
highlighting and code completion for an
assortment of languages let's edit the
batch script to have it describe a
specific workspace if passed as an
argument now let's commit the changes
back into git all we have to do for that
is to type in a GI commit and then a get
push now let's take a look at one of my
favorite AWS Cloud9 features environment
sharing I'm going to share my
environment with my colleague Curtis
[Music]
here Curtis go ahead and make a change
to my bash
script we can see Curtis typing this
live this makes it really easy to do PA
programming that's all we have for you
for today thank you for joining us for
more information check out our other
videos in our series or visit our aw's
